author: By Shane Goldmacher and Jeremy W. Peters
title: How Ginsburg’s Death Has Reshaped the Money Race for Senate Democrats
description: From Alaska to Maine to the Carolinas, Democratic strategists working on Senate campaigns described a spontaneous outpouring of donations the likes of which they had never seen. A Republican surge is expected as well.
content: For much of 2020, Al Gross’s Senate campaign in Alaska has proceeded as something of an afterthought for most Democrats, a distant contest that was off the radar in terms of determining control of the U.S. Senate. After all, Mr. Gross is not even technically running as a Democrat, an affiliation that might doom him in a conservative state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Ginsburg Will Lie in State in the Capitol, the First Woman to Be Given the Honor
description: The event in Statuary Hall will follow two days in which Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg will lie in repose at the Supreme Court, but outside, because of pandemic precautions.
content: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg will lie in state in the United States Capitol on Friday, an unusual honor for a Supreme Court justice and one that has never before been granted to a woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Pandemic Puts N.Y.C. Hotels on the Brink: ‘A Complete Washout’
description: Several big hotels in the city have announced that they are closed for good, and some experts say that more shutdowns are coming.
content: Many of New York City’s biggest hotels closed their doors in March when the coronavirus wiped out tourism and business travel. The shutdowns were supposed to be temporary, but six months later, with no potential influx of visitors in sight, a wave of permanent closures has begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $990,000 Homes in California
description: A 1926 Tudor Revival in Santa Ana, a Spanish-style house in Solvang and a townhouse overlooking a golf course in Danville.
content: This house, in the Floral Park neighborhood known for its 1920s storybook-style homes, is noted on the city’s historic register as a contributing structure to the character of the area. The owner, who bought it in 2017, has updated the plumbing and HVAC systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Mikaela Shiffrin, Staggered by 2020, Wants to Enjoy Ski Racing Again
description: Her father’s death, pandemic-caused cancellations and a wildfire evacuation gave the World Cup champion a new view on competing: “I want to enjoy it, the way I have enjoyed it in the past.”
content: Usually at this time of year, Mikaela Shiffrin, the seven-time Olympic and world ski champion, is building the mental fortitude to dominate another ski racing season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Minister’s Troubled Son Takes Center Stage in Marilynne Robinson’s ‘Jack’
description: The fourth novel in Robinson’s series about the residents of Gilead, Iowa, features a fraught love during the Jim Crow era.
content: The good news about “Jack,” the fourth in Marilynne Robinson’s series of novels about the residents of the small town of Gilead, Iowa, is announced in its title. John Ames “Jack” Boughton, the miscreant son of the town’s Presbyterian minister, is among the more memorable characters in recent American literature. We’ve met him before in these novels. (The previous ones are “Gilead,” “Home” and “Lila.”) He’s a welcome disturber of the peace. Come on in, Jack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Trump Jump-Starts Misinformation on Ginsburg’s ‘Dying Wish’
description: Baseless claims about the legitimacy of the justice’s final statements were not circulating online in any significant way before the president said them on Fox News.
content: President Trump routinely passes along false and misleading information that has been circulating online. On Monday, he appeared to be the one starting it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Joyce
title: Tourism Slump in Dublin Lays Bare Airbnb’s Damage to Rental Markets
description: After the pandemic hit, the number of longer-term listings jumped in the Irish capital. That brought some relief to a crunched market for renters, though it may not last.
content: The modern one-bedroom Dublin apartment featured an open-plan living space, a sun-soaked balcony, solar panels, ample storage space and parking for two cars. The location was ideal, as was the price: about $1,800 a month — $300 less than the previous tenant had paid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner and David Ryder
title: Pandemic, Unrest, Fires? An M.L.B. Rookie Still Smashes Home Runs
description: Kyle Lewis of the Seattle Mariners is a top contender for the American League Rookie of the Year Award in a shortened season upended by postponements and delays.
content: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Lewis’s first two installments here and here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K.’s Boris Johnson to Order Pubs and Restaurants to Close Early
description: As Britain endures a second wave of coronavirus, experts fear much worse is yet to come. But critics argue that restrictions damage the economy and threaten liberties.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain plans to impose new restrictions on nightlife, including the forced early closure of pubs and restaurants in England, as he ramps up the country’s efforts to curb a rising tide of coronavirus infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: N.I.H. Official Departs After Anonymous Posts Attacking Public Health Leaders
description: A managing editor of the right-wing website RedState appeared to attack Dr. Anthony S. Fauci and spread misinformation about the coronavirus pandemic while working for Dr. Fauci’s agency.
content: WASHINGTON — The National Institutes of Health said on Monday that one of its public affairs officers would retire after he was revealed to be surreptitiously attacking his employer and one of its directors, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, in pseudonymous posts on Twitter and the right-wing website RedState.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The G.O.P. Push for Quick Confirmation of a New Justice
description: Readers discuss the intense political battle taking place.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 2 of the N.F.L. Season
description: The Falcons collapsed as only the Falcons can, the Chargers nearly shocked the Chiefs, injuries were everywhere and the Ravens simply never lose (in the regular season).
content: After Week 1 was defined by huge upsets, some order has been restored to the N.F.L. this week with 14 of 15 favorites prevailing leading into Monday night’s game in Las Vegas. And the lone favorite to lose was the Eagles, who were favored by just 1.5 points at home. The road to those victories was rocky, however, as several star players have been lost to injuries — some of which appear to be season-ending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynn Vavreck and Chris Tausanovitch
title: Americans Mostly Agree on Policing. The Difference Is Priorities.
description: Why has it become a big election issue? Democrats prioritize banning chokeholds, and Republicans are focused on not defunding the police.
content: Even as a pandemic and the resulting economic crisis occupy much of the news, President Trump and Joe Biden often talk about something else: crime and justice. Specifically, they are talking about policing and safety, while offering sharply competing visions of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Waldock
title: How Can You Be an Ally? Go to a Black-Owned Bank
description: If you’re looking for innovative ways beyond the ballot box to be an ally, look to the small and minority-owned banks anchoring your community.
content: Four years before this summer of unrest in New York City, I attended the protests after Alton Sterling and Philando Castile were shot and killed by police officers that July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: ‘You Would Do the Same’: Graham Is Defiant on Supreme Court Reversal
description: Senator Lindsey Graham said he would refuse to confirm a Republican’s Supreme Court nominee in a presidential election year. Now he is rushing to deliver President Trump’s third justice.
content: When Senator Lindsey Graham joined a Republican blockade of President Barack Obama’s Supreme Court nominee in 2016, he went out of his way to frame his position that a confirmation to the court should never be allowed in an election year as principled, apolitical and utterly permanent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: New Zealand restrictions, TikTok, Supreme Court: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced that virus restrictions on travel and gatherings would be lifted across most of New Zealand this week. In most of the country, New Zealanders were freed of rules put in place to curb the spread of the virus on Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: An Alaska Mine Project Might Be Bigger Than Acknowledged
description: In secretly recorded meetings, executives with the Pebble Mine project said the operation could run nine times longer than outlined in their permit filings.
content: Executives overseeing the development of a long-disputed copper and gold mine in Alaska were recorded saying they expected the project to become much bigger, and operate for much longer, than outlined in the proposal that is awaiting final approval by the Army Corps of Engineers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Trump Needs a Tutorial on How International Agreements Work
description: The administration is arguing that it is still a party to the Iran deal that it left with great fanfare in 2018.
content: Two years ago, the Trump administration withdrew from an international agreement that had lifted most sanctions on Iran in exchange for strict limits on Iran’s nuclear program. President Trump called the accord, which had been painstakingly negotiated by the Obama administration and America’s closest European allies, the “worst deal ever.” He has been trying to kill it ever since. He reimposed economic sanctions and threatened secondary sanctions on European allies that do any business with Iran. The repudiation was so head-spinning that other countries now wonder if American international commitments can be trusted to last beyond the next election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: YoungBoy Never Broke Again Earns a Third No. 1 Album in a Year
description: “Top” opened at the top of the Billboard 200 with the equivalent of 126,000 sales, demonstrating the power of frequently delivering new music.
content: This summer, Daniel Ek, one of the founders of Spotify, drew jeers for suggesting in an interview that artists should now continually pump out content, and that in the “future landscape” of streaming, “you can’t record music once every three to four years and think that’s going to be enough.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Estate’s Racially Divisive Name Threatens Future of Premier Equestrian Event
description: The Olympic equestrian sport of eventing will no longer be held at a Pennsylvania estate that has resisted calls to change its name, which some say evokes slavery.
content: For two decades, the Olympic equestrian sport of eventing has held prestigious competitions on a Pennsylvania estate with a landscape perfect for horses and riders to demonstrate strength, endurance and grace while jumping over a variety of solid and natural obstacles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘Welcome to the New World,’ by Jake Halpern and Michael Sloan: An Excerpt
description: A new graphic novel expands on the Pulitzer-winning series about the challenges a family of Syrian refugees faced in America.
content: For nearly a year, Jake Halpern followed a family of Syrian refugees who arrived in the United States on Election Day of 2016 as they navigated the first day of school, learned English — and received a death threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: This Year’s Emmy Winners Want You to Vote
description: Racial justice and Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s legacy were also recurring themes during Sunday night’s ceremony.
content: As vigils honoring Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the Supreme Court justice who died on Friday, continued throughout the United States on Sunday, television stars gathered virtually for the 72nd Primetime Emmy Awards, one of the first major awards shows to take place during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Climate change? U.S. oil giants are doubling down on fossil fuels.
description: European energy companies like BP, Royal Dutch Shell and others have lately been selling off oil fields and investing billions in renewable energy, a response to plunging oil prices and growing concerns about climate changes.
content: European energy companies like BP, Royal Dutch Shell and others have lately been selling off oil fields and investing billions in renewable energy, a response to plunging oil prices and growing concerns about climate changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: N.Y.P.D. Officer Is Accused of Spying on Tibetans for China
description: Prosecutors said the officer told Chinese consulate officials that he could provide sensitive information about the internal operations of the Police Department.
content: Federal prosecutors on Monday charged a New York City police officer with acting as an illegal agent of the Chinese government, accusing him of providing intelligence about Tibetans living in the United States to officials at the Chinese consulate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Jentleson
title: Democrats Need a Plan. Fast.
description: Here’s how they can apply maximum pressure, brand the process as the illegitimate farce it is and lay the groundwork for desperately needed reform.
content: The temperature plummeted Friday night in Washington, along with the mood of many Democrats, as they heard that Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg had passed away. In the fight to fill her seat, the stakes are enormous and Democrats need a plan — fast. Their options in the weeks ahead are limited, but Republicans face a slim margin for error.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Learn to Argue Productively’
description: In this lesson, part of our suite of resources for our Civil Conversation Challenge, students will practice putting six practical tips into action — in person and online.
content: Featured Article: “Learn to Argue Productively” by Harry Guinness
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Was That Ride on the Trump Train Worth It?
description: The president has proved as hazardous to his allies as to his enemies.
content: Lurching through his presidency with equal parts venality and incompetence, Donald Trump gives little thought to the chaos he leaves in his wake. Little wonder that his tenure has proved hazardous not only for his adversaries and the hapless masses subject to his feeble leadership, but for his allies and enablers as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak
title: ‘Showers and Pants Are So 2019’
description: And other six-word memoirs about the pandemic.
content: Can you sum up the past six months in six words? In a recent Op-Ed, Larry Smith, the creator of the Six Word Memoirs project, observes that times of extremes — “our toughest and most joyous moments” — are often ideal for his brand of succinct storytelling. His collection of pandemic-inspired memoirs, gathered from writers across the country, inspired us to challenge our readers to write theirs too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Prosecutor’s Backstage Tour of the Mueller Investigation
description: Andrew Weissmann, a top lawyer in the special counsel’s office, details the investigators’ findings and frustrations in his new memoir, “Where Law Ends.”
content: There’s something refreshing about an author who harbors no illusions about his own book — especially when that book is about the current occupant of the White House, whose chaotic energy has spawned a booming industry of insider accounts and cris de coeur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias
title: Abortion was on the back-burner in the presidential race. Not anymore.
description: For months, abortion has been relegated to a back burner in the presidential campaign, eclipsed by a worldwide pandemic, an economic crisis and protests over racial justice.
content: For months, abortion has been relegated to a back burner in the presidential campaign, eclipsed by a worldwide pandemic, an economic crisis and protests over racial justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Zendaya Makes History with Her Emmy Win for ‘Euphoria’
description: The 24-year-old star of HBO’s “Euphoria” beat out acclaimed actresses like Jennifer Aniston and Laura Linney, becoming the youngest to win best lead actress in a drama.
content: “She’s younger than Baby Yoda and she already has an Emmy,” Jimmy Kimmel said after a visibly shaken Zendaya, 24, became the youngest Emmy winner for best lead actress in a drama for her role as Rue on HBO’s “Euphoria.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Tyler Perry Gives Rousing Emmys Speech After Receiving Governors Award
description: The award prompted a heartfelt personal story about a quilt made by Perry’s grandmother, and about its symbolic resonance with the experiences of Black Americans.
content: Tyler Perry was honored at the Emmys on Sunday night with one of the Television Academy’s top honors, the Governors Award, which is given to a single person, project or entity for “extraordinary” or “cumulative” accomplishment — effectively a lifetime achievement award for Perry. Past winners include “Star Trek,” “American Idol,” Jerry Lewis and PBS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Mitch McConnell Has Seen the Promised Land
description: Chutzpah doesn’t even begin to cover it.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, it’s as if someone dared 2020 to get worse, and 2020 replied: “Just try me.” Right now I’m just sitting on my porch, awaiting a plague of locusts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Steve Lohr
title: Microsoft Grabs Some of World’s Biggest Games in $7.5 Billion Deal
description: The company’s acquisition of ZeniMax Media puts it in a strong position against Sony just weeks before the release of their next generation of gaming consoles.
content: Microsoft landed a major blow in its decades-long battle with its video game industry rival Sony on Monday, announcing the $7.5 billion acquisition of a video game company that narrowed the gap between the two tech giants’ offerings.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At the U.N., a General Assembly Like No Other
description: As world leaders meet for the 75th United Nations General Assembly this week, the gatherings are virtual, but the challenges all too real.
content: The General Assembly will begin its annual speeches by world leaders on Tuesday, but on Monday it held a separate and largely virtual gathering to commemorate the passage of the United Nations into its fourth quarter-century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jasmin Malik Chua
title: Are Exotic Skins Out of Fashion?
description: Covid-19 may be the tipping point when it comes to crocodile, python, ostrich, and clothes.
content: Something was clearly missing from Stockholm Fashion Week’s virtual catwalk on Aug. 25, and it wasn’t just a physical audience.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Upends College Admissions Tests, Creating Chaos for Students
description: An Iowa school district that defied a reopening order is moving toward a “hybrid” model. South Korea suspends a plan to provide free flu shots to 19 million people.
content: After a spring and summer when most opportunities to take college admissions tests were lost to the pandemic, many students were counting on taking the ACT on Saturday, one of the first big standardized testing dates of the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Blankets
description: Because it may not be cold yet, but it will be soon.
content: As evenings turn colder, blankets are useful just about everywhere: by the fire, in front of the television, on top of the bed. But they work well as decorative accents at almost any time of year — especially when they have vibrant colors and patterns.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When F. Murray Abraham and Ruth Bader Ginsburg Met in Venice
description: The actor recalls a chance encounter that led to a memorable performance. Also: The blue states have it.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Emmy Show Reinvents Itself, but Keeps the Stale Parts
description: The mostly virtual Emmys telecast dispensed with many award-show trappings, but continued its trend of feeling out of tune with the way most of us watch TV.
content: Nothing in ABC’s broadcast of the 2020 Emmy Awards was as impressive, or as appropriate to the occasion, as the aplomb with which the first presenter, Jennifer Aniston, wielded a fire extinguisher. Unfortunately, she was only shooting foam at a prop envelope in an endless coronavirus routine. She couldn’t put out the dumpster fire that was going on all around her at the Staples Center on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and William K. Rashbaum
title: Trump Could Be Investigated for Tax Fraud, D.A. Says for First Time
description: A new court filing from the Manhattan district attorney offered rare insight into the office’s investigation of the president and his businesses.
content: The Manhattan district attorney’s office, which has been locked in a yearlong legal battle with President Trump over obtaining his tax returns, suggested for the first time in a court filing on Monday that it had grounds to investigate him and his businesses for tax fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: As the Supreme Court fight heats up, Biden urges Republican senators to ‘follow your conscience.’
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. urged Republicans on Sunday not to rush a Supreme Court nominee through the Senate in the final six weeks before the presidential election, suggesting that such a move would amount to an “abuse of power” at an already perilous moment in American political history.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. urged Republicans on Sunday not to rush a Supreme Court nominee through the Senate in the final six weeks before the presidential election, suggesting that such a move would amount to an “abuse of power” at an already perilous moment in American political history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: antithesis
description: This word has appeared in 78 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: Can you grok “grok”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yossy Arefi
title: The Perfect Afternoon Snack Has Arrived
description: With its sunny lemon glaze, this one-bowl carrot loaf cake is as easy to eat as it is to make.
content: Comforting and cozy, but still light and bright, a carrot cake with a tangy lemon glaze is just the thing for when you want a bit of fall flavor but aren’t quite ready to break into the pumpkin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: U.S. and European Oil Giants Go Different Ways on Climate Change
description: While BP and other European companies invest billions in renewable energy, Exxon and Chevron are committed to fossil fuels and betting on moonshots.
content: HOUSTON — As oil prices plunge and concerns about climate change grow, BP, Royal Dutch Shell and other European energy companies are selling off oil fields, planning a sharp reduction in emissions and investing billions in renewable energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Jeff Zucker Helped Create Donald Trump. That Show May Be Ending.
description: The coziness between the TV executive and Mr. Trump is a Frankenstein story for the cable news era. But then the monster got away.
content: In December 2015, after the demagoguery of Donald Trump’s presidential campaign became clear, I asked CNN’s president, Jeff Zucker, if he regretted his role in Mr. Trump’s rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Catherine O’Hara Wins First Acting Emmy
description: O’Hara was named best lead actress in a comedy for playing the campy former soap star Moira Rose on “Schitt’s Creek.”
content: From a scorched envelope — “to burn off all the germs,” he said — Jimmy Kimmel virtually presented Catherine O’Hara with her first Emmy Award for acting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar and Shannon Doyne
title: Justice Ginsburg Fought for Gender Equality. How Close Are We to Achieving That Goal?
description: Her vision was once seen as radical. What work still needs to be done to end discrimination based on sex?
content: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the second woman to serve on the Supreme Court and a pioneering advocate for women’s rights, died on Friday. She spent much of her career advancing the legal principle that men and women should be equal, and that the law should treat them as such. To what extent do you think we have achieved equality of the sexes? To what extent have we accomplished what Linda Greenhouse, a contributing writer and former Supreme Court correspondent for The Times, describes as Justice Ginsburg’s “radical project”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Law Firms Pay Supreme Court Clerks $400,000 Bonuses. What Are They Buying?
description: Inside information and influence with the clerks’ former bosses may figure in the transactions, a new study suggests.
content: WASHINGTON — Supreme Court justices make $265,600 a year. The chief justice gets $277,700.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Parents, How Are You Doing?
description: We’d love to hear how you’re dealing with remote learning and getting your kids — and yourself — through these uncertain days.
content: If your kids are taking their classes online — either entirely or a few days a week — because of the coronavirus crisis, we’d love to hear from you. What is your best advice for other parents in a similar situation? Is there a way that you’ve set up your home or dealt with technology problems? Are you making small changes to your family routine or just throwing it away altogether? And … how are you managing to work with your kids at home?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Former World Leaders Urge Ratification of Nuclear Arms Ban Treaty
description: In an open letter, the onetime leaders implored their own governments to embrace an arms treaty negotiated at the U.N. three years ago. It is six ratifications short of the 50 needed to go into effect.
content: Fifty-six former prime ministers, presidents, foreign ministers and defense ministers from 20 NATO countries, plus Japan and South Korea, released an open letter Sunday imploring their current leaders to join the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons, the pact negotiated in 2017 that is now just six ratifications shy of the 50 needed to take effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Margulies
title: Kids Need Superheroes Now More Than Ever
description: If Captain America can defeat the Red Skull, a child can conquer her anxiety of a Zoom class.
content: On a weekday morning in March, early into the pandemic, my 4-year-old daughter refused to join her preschool class on Zoom. Uninterested in seeing the faces of her friends and teachers, whom she had to abruptly say goodbye to only a week earlier, she instead started digging through her bin of dress-up clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘A Cry in the Dark’ and ‘The Masked Singer’
description: Meryl Streep plays a mother accused of murder in the 1988 film, Time magazine will unveil its list of the 100 most influential people on ABC and a wacky singing competition series returns for its fourth season.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, September 21-27. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2020 Emmys
description: The pandemic forced the Emmy Awards to stage a largely virtual event. Here are the highs and lows of the ceremony.
content: With the pandemic making packed red carpets and large, glitzy gatherings impossible, almost no one knew what the 72nd Primetime Emmy Awards ceremony would look like going into Sunday night’s telecast.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nancy Pelosi: ‘If The Election Were Held Today, We Would Win It All’
description: The most powerful woman in America plans to prevail in November. But what are the limits to her influence? Listen to the premiere of “Sway” with Kara Swisher.
content: In the inaugural episode of Kara Swisher’s new podcast, “Sway,” she interviews House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. When it comes to presidential succession, Ms. Pelosi is second in line. And when it comes to taking on President Trump, she’s usually first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: For Older People, Reassuring News in the Statin Debate
description: There is accumulating evidence that the benefits of statins far outweigh possible risks, and nearly all statins on the market are now available as inexpensive generics.
content: Cholesterol-lowering statin drugs, already one of the most popular medications worldwide, may become even more widely used as evidence grows of their safety and value to the elderly and their potential benefits beyond the heart and blood vessels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles
title: Some Protests Against Police Brutality Take a More Confrontational Approach
description: The protests are moving into white residential neighborhoods, where activists demand that people choose a side.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Terrance Moses was watching protesters against police brutality march down his quiet residential street one recent evening when some in the group of a few hundred suddenly stopped and started yelling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
title: As School Begins, Mothers Working Retail Jobs Feel Extra Burden
description: A number of women working in retail say they are being forced to choose between keeping their jobs and making sure their children can keep up with remote learning.
content: The start of the virtual school year has been a struggle for Patricia Reveles, a pharmacy technician at a CVS in Los Angeles, whose daughter is in fourth grade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: Photoville Adds New Venues, Vistas and Vision
description: A joyous jumble of 60-plus shows in five boroughs, it is a reminder of photography’s power not just to document crisis, but to help imagine better lives.
content: The container village is gone. Photoville, the pop-up fall festival that turns the waterfront under the Brooklyn Bridge into a friendly encampment for photography buffs and the general public, has dispensed in its ninth year, for coronavirus reasons, with its architectural signature, converted shipping containers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and Emily Flitter
title: A trove of bank reports shows the widespread flow of illicit money.
description: A cache of thousands of reports that major banks filed with federal regulators shows that they helped suspected terrorists, drug dealers and corrupt foreign officials move trillions of dollars around the world, despite the banks’ concerns about the suspicious nature of the transactions.
content: A cache of thousands of reports that major banks filed with federal regulators shows that they helped suspected terrorists, drug dealers and corrupt foreign officials move trillions of dollars around the world, despite the banks’ concerns about the suspicious nature of the transactions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: F.B.I. Investigates Louisiana Man’s Death After Police Chase
description: The Louisiana State Police said Ronald Greene died in a crash after leading troopers on a high-speed chase. Over a year later, photos of his injuries have raised new questions about his death.
content: Federal authorities have opened a civil rights investigation and a Louisiana State Police trooper has been placed on leave as new questions have surfaced about the death of a Black man after a high-speed chase in northern Louisiana last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Advice on Virus Transmission Vanishes From C.D.C. Website
description: The new guidance, published only on Friday, had acknowledged that fine particles floating in air may spread the virus.
content: Just days after publishing significant new guidance on airborne transmission of the coronavirus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Monday withdrew the advice, saying only that it had been “posted in error” on the agency’s website.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Sept. 21, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 21, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 21, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Kaplan
title: Aromatherapy in the Apiary Is What Bees Need
description: Honeybees were better at pollinating crops after scent training.
content: To fill your homes with blueberries, sunflowers and almonds, farmers rent honeybees. When all goes well, the bees pollinate the flowers, resulting in ample yields. But sometimes the rental bees buzz off and pollinate wildflowers instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Will the Senate Follow Its Own Precedent?
description: President Trump wants a vote on his next Supreme Court nominee “without delay”: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: The Supreme Court is all about setting precedent, right? The Senate, apparently not so much. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: R.I.P., R.B.G. What’s Next?
description: The Supreme Court vacancy has only injected more chaos into the election. There are opportunities and perils for both parties.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Voting G.O.P. Means Voting Against Health Care
description: The death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg has only raised the stakes.
content: If you or someone you care about are among the more than 50 million Americans suffering from pre-existing medical conditions, you should be aware that the stakes in this year’s election go beyond abstract things like, say, the survival of American democracy. They’re also personal. If Donald Trump is re-elected, you will lose the protection you’ve had since the Affordable Care Act went into effect almost seven years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janie Osborne
title: In Montana, the Art of Crafting Fly-Fishing Rods
description: “One thing about Montana,” says Matt Barber, an owner of Tom Morgan Rodsmiths, a custom fly rod shop in Bozeman, “is if there’s a moving body of water, there is probably a trout in it.”
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Janie Osborne shares a collection of images from Montana.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s Life, and the Battle for Her Seat
description: In a two-part special, we reflect on the achievements of an American legal giant and examine the fight to replace her on the Supreme Court.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: One Musician’s Plan to Make the Concert Industry More Diverse
description: Noelle Scaggs from Fitz and the Tantrums has an initiative, Diversify the Stage, that aims to direct more touring business opportunities to people of color, women, and L.G.B.T.Q. people.
content: Shortly before Covid-19 shut the concert industry down, Noelle Scaggs, one of the singers in the alt-pop band Fitz and the Tantrums, began noticing that there was seldom anyone else like her on the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Canadians Rejoice as ‘Schitt’s Creek’ Sweeps Emmy Awards
description: The Canadian series took top honors in all seven categories in which it was nominated.
content: Prince Harry and Meghan took a stab at living in British Columbia before decamping for Los Angeles. Madonna pronounced their entire country “boring.” But Canadians will always have the 2020 Emmys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Speculation builds over whether enough Republicans will back Trump’s Supreme Court plans.
description: President Trump’s announcement of a nominee to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court is expected as early as this week, a development that will reshape the presidential campaign and draw intense scrutiny to a handful of Republican senators who will determine how the process moves forward.
content: President Trump’s announcement of a nominee to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court is expected as early as this week, a development that will reshape the presidential campaign and draw intense scrutiny to a handful of Republican senators who will determine how the process moves forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Roy Hammond, Soul Singer Who Birthed a Hip-Hop Heartbeat, Dies at 81
description: He wrote and produced the Honey Drippers’ “Impeach the President,” which has been sampled countless times and changed the sound of New York rap.
content: Roy Hammond, a soul singer, songwriter and producer with an impressive catalog in the 1960s and ’70s who produced a song that became one of hip-hop’s foundational samples, died on Wednesday at his home in Allendale, S.C. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Madrid Opera Shut Down by Audience Angry at Crowding in Cheap Seats
description: Spectators in the mezzanine, which had less spare space than more expensive areas, shouted and clapped until the performance was abandoned.
content: MADRID — A major uptick in coronavirus cases in Spain has renewed all sorts of tensions — even within the capital’s royal opera house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: An Open Letter to Mitt Romney
description: Here’s why Lindsey Graham is wrong.
content: Dear Senator Romney,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: LeBron James and the Burden of Being Great(est)
description: He is miffed about not winning the M.V.P. Award, and rightfully so. His magic on and off the court is often unfairly taken for granted.
content: Poor LeBron James. There he is again, battling into the deep muck of the N.B.A. playoffs, leading his team oh-so-close to a world title. And there he is: An omnipresent force in purple-striped high-tops, so consistently great on the biggest stage that we have come to expect nothing less.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden will be in Wisconsin today as Trump heads to Ohio.
description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Playing Jesus in a Pandemic Summer
description: Nicholas Edwards starred in the closely watched “Godspell” production. “Usually the stage is a safe place,” he said, “but it became a place where I was anxious all the time.”
content: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — On Sunday afternoon, Nicholas Edwards rolled the white gaiter over his nose and mouth for the last time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Billy Porter Leads Hollywood Diversity Push in Emmys Ad
description: Daniel Dae Kim, Lin-Manuel Miranda and Isis King also take part in a 60-second spot demanding real inclusion in the entertainment industry.
content: The field of Emmy nominees is more diverse than it has been in previous years, but a number of prominent actors, writers and producers say Hollywood can do more, a message they put across in a 60-second commercial that aired on ABC during the annual awards ceremony on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Jerry Harris to Remain in Custody After Arrest on Child Pornography Charge
description: A lawyer for Mr. Harris, star of the Emmy-winning Netflix series “Cheer,” waived his initial hearings on Monday.
content: Jerry Harris, the breakout star of the Emmy-winning Netflix series “Cheer” who was arrested last week and charged with producing child pornography, will remain in custody, a court decided on Monday. His lawyer waived both his detention and preliminary hearings at a 10-minute hearing in a federal court in Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe, Ana Swanson and Michael J. de la Merced
title: TikTok Deal Trips Over U.S.-China Power Struggle
description: Companies involved in a deal to resolve TikTok’s future publicly clashed over the arrangement, while President Trump threatened to block any deal that left the service in Chinese hands.
content: WASHINGTON — A deal intended to address the Trump administration’s concerns about TikTok’s ties to China was complicated on Monday by a disagreement over whether a U.S. company would control the social media app and the president’s threat to block any agreement that leaves the service in the hands of a Chinese company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: ‘Coloured Lives Matter’: A South African Police Shooting Like No Other
description: He was a young man from the projects gunned down by officers near his home. But race is complicated in South Africa, and so is his story.
content: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa — The deadly encounter between the police and a young man from the projects, set off public outrage with all the familiar scenes: shrines of flowers and stuffed animals, clouds of tear gas and barrages of rocks aimed at officers in riot gear, and impassioned slogans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Surrendered Court Seats
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: In the final decades of the 20th century, liberals and conservatives each had their own problem that kept their preferred judges from dominating the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Mix of Joy and Confusion as School Doors Open for Youngest in N.Y.C.
description: Up to 90,000 children in pre-K and students with advanced disabilities returned to in-person school on Monday.
content: Early on Monday, Tiyanna Jackson, who had quit her job in the spring to care for her 4-year-old daughter, Zuri, was flooded with relief as she arrived at a pre-K center in the South Bronx. Finally, with Zuri starting school, she could get back to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Belarus, Aleksei Navalny: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: How Can I Avoid Feeling Lonely When All My Friends Are Coupled Up?
description: “When confronted with forces beyond our control, isolation can be a form of escape and self-preservation,” writes one of our advice columnists.
content: In T’s advice column, Culture Therapist, either Ligaya Mishan or Megan O’Grady solves your problems using art. Have a question? Need some comfort? Email us at advice@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: For Young People’s Sexual Health, the Pandemic Changes the Game
description: The pandemic may offer opportunities to help adolescents and young adults make good decisions regarding sexual and social behavior.
content: Experts in adolescent sexual health are concerned that the coronavirus pandemic will have serious effects on the sexual health and social behavior of young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: To Protest Colonialism, He Takes Artifacts From Museums
description: Mwazulu Diyabanza will appear in a Paris court this month after he tried to make off with an African treasure he says was looted. France and its attitude to the colonial past will be on trial, too.
content: PARIS — Early one afternoon in June, the Congolese activist Mwazulu Diyabanza walked into the Quai Branly Museum, the riverfront institution that houses treasures from France’s former colonies, and bought a ticket. Together with four associates, he wandered around the Paris museum’s African collections, reading the labels and admiring the treasures on show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: The Supreme Court opening quickly becomes a central issue in Maine’s Senate race.
description: An ad focusing on the Supreme Court vacancy after the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is hitting the airwaves in a critical Senate race, as Sara Gideon, the Democratic challenger to Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, has made Ms. Collins’s support of President Trump’s past nominees an issue in a new ad.
content: An ad focusing on the Supreme Court vacancy after the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is hitting the airwaves in a critical Senate race, as Sara Gideon, the Democratic challenger to Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, has made Ms. Collins’s support of President Trump’s past nominees an issue in a new ad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchir Sharma
title: Is the Stock Market Rooting for Trump or Biden?
description: Neither. Wall Street is not as partisan as you think.
content: For months the S&P 500 rose this year — despite a deadly pandemic, the resulting economic devastation and the rise of a Democratic Party increasingly sympathetic to democratic socialism. Then, this month, with Joe Biden doing well in the polls, stock prices finally stumbled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Adam Liptak
title: Lagoa’s Role in Florida Will Be a Big Factor in Trump’s Supreme Court Pick
description: Judge Barbara Lagoa lacks some of the usual credentials of a Supreme Court justice, but her roots in the Cuban-American community could make her an attractive choice for President Trump.
content: MIAMI — As a young associate in a prestigious Miami law firm, Barbara Lagoa took on an unusual pro bono case, one without a supervising partner and against a formidable adversary: the Clinton administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: How Facebook Can Slow QAnon for Real
description: Social media sites cracked down on terrorist recruitment. Imagine what they could do about QAnon.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: How One District Reopened Its Classrooms
description: Most lower-income students are learning online. But in Cajon Valley, Calif., they’re back in school. Here’s how they did it.
content: This spring, when school moved online in Cajon Valley, Calif., lower-income parents struggled to balance work and home instruction. Students — most of them poor enough to receive free or subsidized lunches — struggled to connect to lessons online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson and Abby Goodnough
title: If the Supreme Court Ends Obamacare, Here’s What It Would Mean
description: The Affordable Care Act touches the lives of most Americans, and its abolition could have a significant effect on many millions more people than those who get their health coverage through it.
content: What would happen if the Supreme Court struck down the Affordable Care Act?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Shawn Hubler
title: Donald Trump vs. the Ivy League: An Election-Year Battle
description: Mr. Trump, himself an Ivy League graduate, has made Princeton, Harvard and other elite colleges targets this year.
content: When it comes to criticizing the nation’s most elite universities, the Trump administration has had a busy year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tessa Paoli and Nina Sparling
title: An Update on Project Roomkey in Tuolumne County
description: Monday: A pandemic program publicized by the state faced challenges in implementation.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Our 2020 Civil Conversation Challenge for Teenagers
description: Beginning Sept. 22 and running through Oct. 30, we’re inviting teenagers to have productive, respectful conversations about some of the issues dividing us this election season.
content: Four years ago we ran an experiment we called our Civil Conversation Challenge. We invited teenagers to come to our site and, via the comments section, have productive and respectful conversations around some of the issues at the center of that year’s election — immigration, gun control, climate change, race and gender, and more. We loved the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: In Latest Legal Rebuke, Court Orders Postal Service to Prioritize Mail-In Voting
description: A federal judge, in response to a lawsuit filed in New York, also ordered the agency to reverse operational changes that have slowed mail delivery in recent months.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in New York on Monday ordered the Postal Service to reverse operational changes that have slowed mail delivery in recent months and to prioritize election mail, the latest legal rebuke to Louis DeJoy’s management of the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Jack Ewing
title: Head of Nikola, a G.M. Electric Truck Partner, Quits Amid Fraud Claims
description: Trevor Milton, founder and executive chairman of Nikola, resigned after an investment fund accused him of making false assertions about his company’s technology.
content: Trevor Milton, a college dropout, turned his entrepreneurial visions into Nikola, a start-up aiming to develop long-haul semi trucks powered by hydrogen and electricity. General Motors was so taken with the idea that it took a $2 billion stake in the company, even though it essentially has no revenue and has not produced a single truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: A Covid-19 Vaccine for Kids May Not Arrive Before Fall 2021
description: While scientists are rushing to develop an immunization for adults, no one has started the process yet for children.
content: The pandemic has many parents asking two burning questions. First, when can I get a vaccine? And second, when can my kids get it? It may come as a surprise that the answers are not the same. Adults may be able to get a vaccine by next summer. But their kids will have to wait longer. Perhaps a lot longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: President Trump says China must cede control of TikTok or he ‘won’t make the deal.’
description: President Trump said on Monday that he would not approve a deal for TikTok if its Chinese owner did not fully sell its interest in the product, a move that would scuttle an arrangement that was expected to help the app avoid a federal ban.
content: President Trump said on Monday that he would not approve a deal for TikTok if its Chinese owner did not fully sell its interest in the product, a move that would scuttle an arrangement that was expected to help the app avoid a federal ban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: TikTok Deal Exposes a Security Gap, and a Missing China Strategy
description: Technological progress has outpaced the political debate again. What will happen when the next TikTok arrives in the United States?
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has declared victory in his latest confrontation with China, saying that he headed off a looming national security threat by forcing the sale of the social media app sensation TikTok to a consortium of American, European and — though he does not say so — Chinese owners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: An Indigenous Canadian Journalist Was Covering a Protest. Then He Got Arrested.
description: He is one of four reporters arrested while covering Indigenous affairs in a country that has been trying to make amends for its colonial past.
content: OTTAWA — The land was theirs, the Indigenous protesters said, and so they tried to prevent the housing project near Niagara Falls from going forward — burning tires to block a highway, spray-painting slogans on the construction company’s equipment and setting an excavator on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israeli Accused of Sex Abuse in Australia Can Be Extradited, Court Says
description: Australia has been seeking Malka Leifer’s extradition for six years so she can face 74 charges of sexual assault stemming from her time as the principal of an ultra-Orthodox school in Melbourne.
content: JERUSALEM — A former principal of a Jewish girls’ school in Australia accused of sexually assaulting her pupils can be extradited to face trial there, a court in Israel ruled on Monday, bringing a yearslong legal saga that has strained relations between the two countries to a potential close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees Clinch Playoff Berth in Pandemic-Shortened Season
description: Despite a loss to the Boston Red Sox, the Yankees are in the postseason because of baseball math dictated by a loss by the Seattle Mariners.
content: Before the 2020 season was originally supposed to begin in late March, the Yankees were considered among the favorites to win the World Series. Most of the team that won 103 games last season and reached the American League Championship Series was back. And they had added one of the best pitchers in baseball, Gerrit Cole, to address a starting rotation weakness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Azi Paybarah
title: Nebraska Bar Owner Who Was Charged in Killing of Black Man Dies by Suicide
description: Jacob Gardner, who was indicted in the killing of James Scurlock during a May protest in Omaha, had been expected to turn himself in to the authorities, his lawyer said.
content: A white bar owner charged in the fatal shooting of a Black man during a protest in Nebraska in May — less than a week after the killing of George Floyd — has died by suicide, the man’s lawyer said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: Why Ruth Bader Ginsburg Refused to Step Down
description: She could have had President Obama nominate her successor. But she didn’t get to the Supreme Court by letting other people tell her what she could do.
content: When I met Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg for the first time in 2008, she took me to see a political cartoon that hung in a hallway outside her chambers at the Supreme Court. The cartoon depicted Belva Lockwood, a lawyer in her 50s, who was the first woman to argue a case before the court, in 1880. Ginsburg noted that the Supreme Court bar initially refused to admit Lockwood several years earlier. In response, Lockwood drafted and lobbied for a bill, which Congress passed, allowing qualified women attorneys to practice in federal court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Robert S. Graetz, Rare White Minister to Back Bus Boycott, Dies at 92
description: Targeted by the Ku Klux Klan, he drove Black people to and from work during the Montgomery boycott and remained an unbowed voice for desegregation.
content: As a young Lutheran minister in Alabama in the 1950s, the Rev. Robert S. Graetz Jr. would alternate his driving routes to thwart attackers. He once measured a 15-inch-deep crater left by a bomb that had targeted his home in Montgomery. And to shield his young children from fear — and the shards of glass that would follow another explosion — he would play a “game” with them in which they would crawl behind a couch when there was a suspicious sound outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Why Ruth Bader Ginsburg Wasn’t All That Fond of Roe v. Wade
description: The late Supreme Court justice believed the landmark ruling was too sweeping and vulnerable to attacks, explains Professor Mary Hartnett, co-author of Justice Ginsburg’s authorized biography
content: — Mary Hartnett, a law professor at Georgetown University and co-author of Justice Ginsburg’s biography
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Jimmy Kimmel’s 2020 Emmys Monologue: ‘You Can’t Have a Virus Without a Host’
description: Kimmel started his pandemic-era monologue by delivering it to a fake audience. “Of course we don’t have an audience,” he quipped. “This isn’t a MAGA rally.”
content: Jimmy Kimmel kicked off the 72nd Primetime Emmy Awards in an understandably strange fashion, given the global pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Without Ginsburg, Supreme Court Could Rule Three Ways on Obamacare
description: Why the Affordable Care Act may still be safe.
content: The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg means the Supreme Court will have a smaller liberal wing when it hears the latest Obamacare challenge in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Glenn Thrush
title: Biden has $466 million in the bank and a huge financial edge on Trump.
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign said on Sunday that it entered September with $466 million in the bank together with the Democratic Party, giving Mr. Biden a vast financial advantage of about $141 million over President Trump as they head into the intense final stretch of the campaign.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign said on Sunday that it entered September with $466 million in the bank together with the Democratic Party, giving Mr. Biden a vast financial advantage of about $141 million over President Trump as they head into the intense final stretch of the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric L. Motley
title: My Unlikely Friendship With Ruth Bader Ginsburg
description: I was a young, African-American Southerner, working in a Republican administration. But I loved Bach’s Goldberg Variations, and that was enough for her.
content: Our improbable friendship began in 2002 at a Georgetown dinner party, and it began with music. Ruth Bader Ginsburg was a Jewish urbanite who had just turned 70 and had been appointed to the U.S. Supreme Court by a Democratic president. I was a 30-year-old African-American from the rural South who had recently arrived in Washington to serve as a special assistant to George W. Bush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Beard Foundation Will Announce a Few More Awards, Despite a Vow Not To
description: After declaring that giving awards was not ‘the right thing to do’ this year, the group will name three design honorees, adding new confusion to the process.
content: Like many other restaurateurs, Lori Chemla has fought to save her business nearly every day since March. Good news was rare, but she got some a few weeks ago from an unexpected corner: She had won an award for outstanding design from the James Beard Foundation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Michael Crowley
title: Biden Courts Obama-Trump Voters as the President Seeks to Hold Them
description: The Democratic nominee, in Wisconsin, tried to place himself on the side of American workers, while Mr. Trump used a trip to Ohio to blame his opponent for job losses there.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. directly appealed on Monday to voters who once supported Barack Obama but were drawn to Donald J. Trump in the 2016 election, visiting a foundry in northeast Wisconsin and accusing the president of turning his back on working people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘Schitt’s Creek’ Sets an Emmy Record
description: In its sixth and final season, the quirky Canadian comedy pulled off a sweep, taking home seven primetime awards and nine Emmys in all.
content: The Emmys lined up dozens of live feeds from nominees in locations all over the world, but it turns out the only one they needed was in Toronto: In its sixth and final season, “Schitt’s Creek” swept the comedy category on Sunday night, taking home seven wins at the 72nd Primetime Emmy Awards. The show won a total of nine Emmys this year, the most ever for a comedy in a single year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: How ‘Sophocles in Staten Island’ Gains in Translation
description: This comic short about an actor and his kids staging Greek tragedies under lockdown slyly comments on links between the politics of the family and the state.
content: Sophocles knew: Every family has its issues. And in his famed Theban plays, the social ramifications of this are devastating. In “Oedipus Rex,” Oedipus kills his father and beds his mother, which causes a plague to descend onto Thebes. In “Antigone,” his daughter Antigone defies her uncle, Creon, and the family strife results in a string of deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump and Democrats Brace for Showdown Over Supreme Court Seat
description: The president’s determination to confirm a replacement for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg before the election set lawmakers on a collision course as Congress deals with other major issues.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump and his adversaries mobilized on Sunday for an epic campaign-season showdown over the future of the Supreme Court even as the nation prepared to honor the life of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in an outdoor viewing to be held according to pandemic-era guidelines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Trying to Hammer Iran With U.N. Sanctions, U.S. Issues More of Its Own
description: The Trump administration targeted Iran’s nuclear and ballistic missile programs after the U.N. refused to enforce international penalties that the U.S. said it had triggered over the weekend.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States issued new economic sanctions against Iran on Monday, inflicting more financial injury on Tehran and insult on American allies as the Trump administration accused other countries of appeasing Iran instead of fostering peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Ex-Georgia Tech Researcher Can Proceed With Lawsuit Against University Officials
description: Ten years after state agents raided his home, an engineer fights to prove he was wrongfully attacked over a computer chip start-up.
content: In 2010, agents with the Georgia Bureau of Investigation raided the Atlanta home and office of Joy Laskar, a professor of electrical engineering at the Georgia Institute of Technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Fearing Players Wouldn’t Listen, La Liga Appealed to Their Kids
description: Facing a long season and a new wave of infections, Spanish soccer officials turned to fans, businesses and even players’ children to warn players about Covid-19.
content: As coronavirus infection rates in Spain started to rise again recently, so did the anxiety among the leaders of Spain’s top soccer league.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Ellen DeGeneres Returns to Show With Apology for Toxic Workplace
description: “Things happen here that never should have happened,” the host says. Warner Bros. started investigating her show in July, after complaints of a toxic workplace culture. Three top producers have been ousted.
content: Ellen DeGeneres started the 18th season of her daytime talk show on Monday with a lengthy apology that addressed reports describing her as a boss who led a toxic workplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: U.N. Assembly, With Very Few Assembled, Marks 75th Year
description: A recorded speech by President Trump was scheduled but conspicuously missing as the United Nations commemorated its founding after World War II.
content: With nods to its founding from the ashes of World War II, the United Nations officially celebrated the organization’s 75th year Monday in a somber and largely virtual event streamed on the internet because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Supreme Court, Europe Lockdowns, Electric Cars: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: A Burmese Kitchen That Combines Fidelity and Freedom
description: While other restaurants have simplified their dishes for takeout, Rangoon offers complex reasons to dine in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn.
content: Rangoon, a Burmese restaurant that opened in Brooklyn this year just in time for the pandemic, is not precisely the place that its owners, Myo Moe and Daniel Bendjy, envisioned. Still, you should go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart and Michael Cooper
title: The Met Opera Fired James Levine, Citing Sexual Misconduct. He Was Paid $3.5 Million.
description: The terms of the settlement between the renowned conductor and the company he shaped have not been previously disclosed.
content: Last summer, Peter Gelb, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, convened the executive committee of the company’s board to announce the end of one of the highest-profile, messiest feuds in the Met’s nearly 140-year history. A bitter court battle had concluded between the company and the conductor James Levine, who had shaped the Met’s artistic identity for more than four decades before his career was engulfed by allegations of sexual improprieties.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Brain Test You Want Your Kid to Fail
description: The Conservation Test
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Conservatives Try to Lock In Power
description: They want to maintain control for generations to come.
content: The death of the iconic Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has shocked the political world, altered the contours of the upcoming election and induced an overwhelming dread among liberals who fear some basic rights could now be in jeopardy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Amid the Outpouring for Ginsburg, a Hint of Backlash
description: The mourning for Ruth Bader Ginsburg has also stirred a long-simmering question: Just whose feminism did she symbolize?
content: The internet had learned to love Ruth Bader Ginsburg, so it was not surprising that when the news of her death broke on Friday evening, social media lit up with outpourings of love and admiration for this diminutive octogenarian who had been cast as an iron-pumping, dissent-slinging legal ninja.
source.name: The New York Times

title: DealBook: How Ginsburg’s Successor Could Remake Business
description: Leading candidates to fill her seat on the Supreme Court are likely to rule in favor of conservative causes that could affect Corporate America.
content: Good Monday. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Threatens to Withhold Federal Funds From N.Y., Seattle and Portland
description: Attorney General William P. Barr criticized the cities for their responses to protests against police brutality. Democrats called it an effort to help President Trump’s re-election campaign.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr on Monday escalated the Trump administration’s attacks on Democratic-led cities by threatening to withhold federal funding from New York, Seattle and Portland, Ore., over their responses to protests against police brutality, portraying them as inadequate as President Trump seeks to make the unrest a cornerstone of his re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: It’s fall, and that means smothered chicken, pork chops and all the apple desserts.
content: Good morning. Tuesday is the autumnal equinox, the sun right above the Equator, the length of day and night the same, a marker of harvest season, the first day of fall. (Confidential to those in Australia and New Zealand: Happy vernal equinox!) I’ll mourn our lost summer with its mask-fogged sunglasses, its distanced yard hangs and awkward picnics, but revel in the cool nights and the promise of dinners rich with gravy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: The N.F.L., After Shunning Las Vegas, Doubles Down With Raiders
description: Monday night, the Las Vegas Raiders play their first game in a new $2 billion stadium, the physical manifestation of a long, slow embrace between the N.F.L. and legal sports wagering.
content: The “Autumn Wind” is still a Raider, but he’s no longer blustering in from the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: This Deal Helped Turn Google Into an Ad Powerhouse. Is That a Problem?
description: The $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick in 2007 was a “game changer.” A growing number of antitrust experts say it’s the sort of deal that should no longer be possible.
content: Google owns the world’s leading search engine, it operates the largest video-hosting service in YouTube, and its popular web browser, email, map and meeting software is used by billions of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: This Spinach-Potato Pie Feels Like a Hug
description: This reassuring dish is just what we need right now, Yotam Ottolenghi writes.
content: LONDON — Recently, when I posted a picture of a homely, frozen-spinach-filled pie on my Instagram, it got a lot of love. Usually, it’s red tomatoes that get the red hearts. It was interesting, then, to think about why this simple pie struck such a “Yes, please!” chord.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Players’ Alliance Gets $10 Million From M.L.B. and Union to Build Diversity
description: The money is a substantial boost to the 12-week-old group formed by current and former players to increase Black participation at all levels of the sport.
content: Major League Baseball and the players’ union have pledged $10 million to the Players Alliance, a nonprofit formed this summer by more than 100 current and former Black players in the wake of George Floyd’s death, aiming to help build Black participation in the sport, from front offices to the diamond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Christian McCaffrey Leads N.F.L. Injured List After Week 2
description: The Carolina Panthers running back’s high ankle sprain is expected to keep him out for four to six weeks. He was among a number of high-profile players to get hurt in Sunday’s games.
content: Despite a Cowboys comeback, a near upset of the Chiefs and another Ravens romp, it was hard not to see injuries as the biggest story of Week 2 of the N.F.L., which began without a slate of preseason games. The long list was topped by several star players, and some of them are unlikely to be seen on the field again this season. And at least one team, the San Francisco 49ers, was hit with a staggering toll. Here’s the rundown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Montoye
title: This Is How Bloomberg Can Help Biden Win Florida
description: Rather than spend his money on TV ads, Michael Bloomberg can re-enfranchise thousands of formerly incarcerated people in the state by paying off debts tied to their sentences.
content: Those of us who can’t tolerate the thought of another four years of this administration are extremely grateful to Michael Bloomberg for his commitment to spend at least $100 million, primarily on television and digital ads, to increase voter turnout in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump and Democrats brace for a showdown over the Supreme Court.
description: President Trump and his adversaries mobilized on Sunday for an epic campaign-season showdown over the future of the Supreme Court, even as the nation prepared to honor the life of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in an outdoor viewing to be held according to pandemic-era guidelines.
content: President Trump and his adversaries mobilized on Sunday for an epic campaign-season showdown over the future of the Supreme Court, even as the nation prepared to honor the life of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in an outdoor viewing to be held according to pandemic-era guidelines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Robert Draper
title: Woman Suspected of Sending Ricin to Trump Is Arrested
description: Envelopes with ricin were intercepted last week on their way to the White House, a sheriff’s office and a detention facility in Texas.
content: WASHINGTON — A Canadian national suspected of having mailed an envelope containing ricin to the White House was arrested on Sunday while trying to enter the United States from Canada, nearly a year after she had been deported from the United States for engaging in criminal activity, according to two American officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: 2 Men Working to Map World War II Bombs Are Killed by One
description: The aid workers had taken the device to the home they were sharing in the Solomon Islands, a country littered with unexploded ordnance.
content: DARWIN, Australia — An Australian and a Briton working to map a deadly legacy of unexploded munitions from World War II have been killed in the South Pacific nation of the Solomon Islands after a bomb they were working on detonated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: In a Desert’s Burning Sands, Shrimp
description: When it rains in Iran’s Dasht-e Lut desert, the ground comes alive with tiny, upside-down crustaceans.
content: In springtime, when the rain gathers into pools in Iran’s Dasht-e Lut Desert, the sand comes alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Nearly 200,000 people in the United States have died from the coronavirus.
content: The United States is about to reach a heartbreaking milestone: Nearly 200,000 people have died from the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: How Does Your Identity Inform Your Political Beliefs and Values?
description: When did you first become aware of having political opinions? What do you think shaped them? Have they changed over time?
content: From Sept. 22 to Sept. 28, our Student Opinion column will be devoted to the issues we’ll be discussing in our Civil Conversation Challenge, but, as always, any teenager is invited to respond. We hope you’ll not only post your own thoughts, but also reply to the comments of others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Jeremy W. Peters
title: Denial and Defiance: Trump and His Base Downplay the Virus Ahead of the Election
description: With resistance to face masks and scorn for science, President Trump and a sizable number of his supporters are pushing an alternate reality minimizing a tragedy that has killed almost 200,000 Americans.
content: Jodee Burton, a retired preschool teacher who now helps with her husband’s logging business, lives on a remote patch in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, a state that has been embroiled in a partisan battle over how to respond to a pandemic that has killed nearly 7,000 people there and almost 200,000 nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats and Republicans Clash Over Spending Bill to Avoid Shutdown
description: Democrats proposed a spending bill that omitted aid for farmers sought by President Trump, drawing Republican ire and leaving the fate of the bill unclear as federal funding is set to lapse.
content: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders clashed on Monday over a stopgap spending bill to stave off a government shutdown at the end of the month, as Democrats put forth a measure that omitted billions of dollars in additional relief that President Trump had promised for farmers battered by his trade policies and the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: New Yorkers Honor Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Child of Brooklyn
description: The late justice grew up in Midwood, formed by its schools, library and synagogue. She was remembered across the borough and city.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Left Litter in the Park? Thailand Officials Will Mail It to Your Home
description: After campers left trash in a national park, park employees tracked them down, mailed the garbage back and reported them to the authorities.
content: HONG KONG — Officials in Thailand had an unorthodox approach to deal with visitors who left a tent filled with litter in a national park: mail the trash to the offenders.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Grim Reminders That Are Hard to Escape
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 21, 2020.
content: “Personally, losing my parents brought out a lot of anger for me. They were stolen from us by a virus that should have been contained months ago.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Mali Appoints New President After Military Coup
description: Regional leaders have insisted the West African country return to civilian rule. The new interim president is a retired colonel and former defense minister who served under the ousted president.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — A military officer who helped depose the president of Mali in a coup last month has announced that a retired colonel will lead the West African country as interim president until elections are held in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Mueller’s Team Should Have Done More to Investigate Trump-Russia Links, Top Aide Says
description: A new book by one of the special counsel’s top deputies, Andrew Weissmann, is the first inside account of the investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — The team led by Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, failed to do everything it could to determine what happened in the 2016 election, shying away from steps like subpoenaing President Trump and scrutinizing his finances out of fear he would fire them, one of Mr. Mueller’s top lieutenants argued in the first insider account of the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Jump-Starts Misinformation on Ginsburg’s ‘Dying Wish’
description: Baseless claims about the legitimacy of the justice’s final statements were not circulating online in any significant way before the president said them on Fox News.
content: Baseless claims about the legitimacy of the justice’s final statements were not circulating online in any significant way before the president said them on Fox News.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Emmys Night 2020, by the Numbers
description: 9: The number of Emmys ‘Schitt’s Creek’ took home, the most ever for a comedy in a single year.

author: By David Marchese
title: Ilhan Omar Is Not Here to Put You at Ease
description: “You’re agitated by my tone because you think people like me should be sitting in a corner, not heard and not seen.”
content: “You’re agitated by my tone because you think people like me should be sitting in a corner, not heard and not seen.”

title: What You Get for $990,000 in California
description: A 1926 Tudor Revival in Santa Ana, a Spanish-style house in Solvang and a townhouse overlooking a golf course in Danville.

author: By Reuters
title: Biden Appeals to Obama Voters Who Backed Trump in Wisconsin
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee, appealed to voters in Manitowoc, Wis., who had supported Barack Obama but backed President Trump in 2016.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee, appealed to voters in Manitowoc, Wis., who had supported Barack Obama but backed President Trump in 2016.
